sn7.22:1.2: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling among the Sakyans where there was a town of the Sakyans named Khomadussa.
sn7.22:1.3: Then the Blessed One dressed and, taking bowl and robe, entered Khomadussa for alms.
sn7.22:1.4: Now on that occasion the brahmin householders of Khomadussa had assembled in council on some business matter while it was drizzling.
sn7.22:1.5: Then the Blessed One approached the council.
sn7.22:1.6: The brahmin householders of Khomadussa saw the Blessed One coming in the distance
sn7.22:1.8: “Who are these shaveling ascetics? Don’t they know the rule of order?”
sn7.22:1.9: Then the Blessed One addressed the brahmin householders of Khomadussa in verse:
sn7.22:2.1: “That is no council where the good are absent;
sn7.22:2.2: They are not the good who don’t speak Dhamma.
sn7.22:2.3: But having abandoned lust, hate, and delusion,
sn7.22:2.4: Those speaking on Dhamma are alone the good.”
sn7.22:3.1: When this was said, the brahmin householders of Khomadussa said to the Blessed One:
sn7.22:3.3: The Dhamma has been made clear in many ways by Master Gotama, as though he were turning upright what had been turned upside down, revealing what was hidden, showing the way to one who was lost, or holding up a lamp in the dark for those with eyesight to see forms.
sn7.22:3.4: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, and to the Dhamma, and to the Bhikkhu Saṅgha.
sn7.22:3.5: Let Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who from today have gone for refuge for life.
